byline.contributor: Al Baker and Nate Schweber contributed reporting.
byline.original: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. and J. DAVID GOODMAN

abstract: Criminal manslaughter charges against New York City Police Officer Peter Liang sets case apart from fatal police encounters involving civilians Michael Brown and Eric Garner; prosecutors say Liang's claim of accidentally firing his gun in Brooklyn stairwell, killing Akai Gurley, does not spare him from criminal culpability; Liang also declined to testify before grand jury, which weakens his defense.
lead_paragraph: The indictment of Officer Peter Liang, who killed an unarmed man, differs from other police shootings because he did not claim he was acting against a threat and therefore can’t claim he was using legitimate force.

headline.main: Basis for Case in Brooklyn Police Shooting: No Threat Led Officer to Fire
headline.print_headline: Basis of Case: No Threat Led Officer to Fire
